mods.note: i J, (D V Telegram From Political Resident, Bushire. To Political Agent, Kawait . No. 772. Dated the 21st October 1936. prDBN’TD*' 2 or inTornfi ti on. India Office telegraphs there has been a Military coup d’etat in Iraq and new Cabinet under HIKMAT SULAIMAN has been formed. Military column has entered Baghdad which is quiet. * -Bri tconsu 1-<r \ (510/2/37) BRITISH EMBASSY, BAGDAD. IA 4th September, 1937. w>vy Dear Agency, We have been asked officially by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to ascertain the nature of the fees and taxes imposed by the Koweiti authorities on the entry of Iraqi livestock into Koweiti territory for grazing purposes. We shall be grateful for any information you can obtain for us on this subject. Yours ever, V ' Hit- Political Agency, KOWEIT. rY* >7. / Xr cJ<_ ^j“W' N:iWTil SAVINGRAH. A xV m Sn Glair by ba^o 12/SAVING. SECRET. Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. 12th April 194 3. jr»M* Rtt&W V* yS Dmied o Addressed to POLITICAL RESIDENT IN THE PERSIAN GULF. repeated to Political Agent Bahrain No.8/SAVING. During the past eighteen months three consignments of Iraqi currency notes have been lost en route from the United King dom; in one case as the result of an air crash off the coast of Spain and the others due to the sinking of ships. 2o It has now come to light that some of the notes lost off the coast of Spain have been negotiated in Bahrain and have Jbeen imported into Iraq. 3. I should appreciate your assistance in endeavouring to establish the channel by which these notes reached the Persian Gulf. For instance the money changers, sarrafs etc® may know if merchant seamen from vessels calling at Bahrain are endeavour ing to cash dinar notes. All local banks have been advised and their correspondents in neighbouring countries have been asked to keep a close check on all Iraq currency received. 4. Some of the lost notes may also have been negotiated at other ports in the Persian Gulf® 5* Enquiries made should be of a most discreet nature in order to avoid arousing any suspicion likely to discredit the Iraqi currency. 6® The numbers of the missing notes are as follows:- Denomination® Value• From. Numbered. ID 100 ID 400,000 A009,251 A013,251 A011,250 A015,250 ID 10 ID 100,000 A125,001 Al35,000 ID 5 ID 200,000 A250,001 A335,001 A275,000 A350,000 ID 1 ID 150,000 0200,001 G350,000 ID i ID 125,000 0550.001 3200.001 C600,000 D400,000 To. X - lost due to air crash off the coast of Spain. ID i ( ID 1,214 ID % 375 , 000 E860,001 Baas*ooi E865,101 S865,301 S865,7 01 E885, 001 E885, 801 E200,001 G450,001 ID1,351,214 3861.000 3865, 004 B865,227 3865,600 3866, 000 E885,600 3885,897 3200.000 G950,000 / 7This telegram is being repeated to the Political Agent Bahrain in order that enquiries may be initiated there with the minimum of delay. CORNWALLIS . British Residency & Consulate-General, Bushire, Dated the 30th April 4,94 3. Copy forwarded, with compliments, to The Political Agent, TTiiwo t . Kuwait. The Political Agent, Muscat•

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 2/12 Miscellaneous papers relating to Kuwait-Iraq relations'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 9; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-7; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence relating variously to customs duties on livestock, political events in Iraq, and deficiency in printed Iraqi currency due to accidents in transportation. The correspondence consists of exchanges between the British authorities in the Persian Gulf and Iraq.
